author: wjmelements
content:
I think EOF needs `PAY` for security if it won't have `CALL`. The workaround is to `EXTCALL` the value into a legacy contract and `CALL` with `0` gas. But `PAY` is strictly better because there is only one value transfer.

It's useful security-wise to be able to block re-entry on an ether payment. This is one of the reasons that the callvalue stipend is not enough gas to SSTORE or call with value. While re-entry can be protected with `TLOAD`/`TSTORE`, simple ether payments are the main I still use less than `GAS` for the gas parameter of `CALL`. Especially with eip-7702 you do not want to grant control to the recipient just to pay them. They might even be an account unknown to you, as is the case for `COINBASE` payments.

`PAY` is in the spirit of EOF because it doesn't have a gas parameter. It doesn't enable anything not already possible, because it is still possible to pay an account without its permission via `COINBASE` priority fees. It is not a complex opcode to add. Please consider it. Thank you.

author: _shemnon
content: `EXTCALL` is functionally identical to `CALL` with rule-defined gas and zero return buffer. There is no limitation or alteration to the targets of `CALL`. How does the lack of a return buffer and no variable gas create a need for `PAY` any greater than currently exists?

author: wjmelements
content: Currently you can specify `0` gas to `CALL`.

We need to be prepared for PeerDAS to say on 1 May "we are ready to ship" and also be ready to ship.
